channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Benefit payments cap rollout begins
item.description: A government-imposed limit on benefit payments begins in four London boroughs ahead of its introduction across England, Scotland and Wales.

item.title: Minimum wage to increase to £6.31
item.description: The national minimum wage will rise by 12p an hour to £6.31 for adults and by 5p to £5.03 for 18-to-20-year-olds from October.

item.title: Thatcher funeral rehearsal staged
item.description: A military rehearsal of Lady Thatcher's funeral procession takes place in central London, two days ahead of the ceremony at St Paul's Cathedral.

item.title: BBC stands by show in N Korea row
item.description: The BBC says an edition of Panorama filmed secretly on a study trip to North Korea will be aired later despite claims students were put in danger.

item.title: Venezuela challenger demands recount
item.description: Defeated Venezuelan presidential candidate Henrique Capriles demands a recount of votes, rejecting the election of Nicolas Maduro as "illegitimate".

item.title: Iraq cities hit by deadly bombings
item.description: Officials say at least 20 people have been killed and more than 100 others wounded in a series of early morning explosions across Iraq.

item.title: Firms count cost of cold weather
item.description: Both retailers and small businesses say the exceptionally cold weather in March damaged business activity.

item.title: Greece 'to return to growth in 2014'
item.description: The European Commission and other international creditors to Greece say the country's economy will start growing again next year.

item.title: N Korea marks Kim Il-sung birthday
item.description: North Korea celebrates one of its biggest public holidays - the birth of its founding father - as efforts continue to calm tensions in the region.

item.title: Wordpress attacked by giant botnet
item.description: The Wordpress blogging platform, which hosts more than 64 million websites, has been attacked by a huge botnet

item.title: School measles jab clinics for 2,000
item.description: About 2,000 pupils could be given the MMR jab in schools this week after the Easter holidays to stop the spread of the measles epidemic centred on Swansea.

item.title: Anger at Bieber's Anne Frank message
item.description: Justin Bieber faces a public backlash over his note in the Anne Frank Museum's guestbook, saying he hoped the Holocaust victim would have been a fan.

item.title: Soap actor denies child sex charges
item.description: A former Coronation Street actor pleads not guilty to sexually assaulting a teenage boy.

item.title: Vending machines sell art for £1
item.description: Thousands of miniature works of art are sold from vending machines in Leeds for £1 each in an attempt to make art more accessible.

item.title: Women lack mentality for F1 - Moss
item.description: Former British racing driver Sir Stirling Moss believes women do not have the mental skills to race competitively in Formula 1.

item.title: Hoy expected to announce retirement
item.description: Six-time Olympic champion Sir Chris Hoy is expected to retire from cycling on Thursday at the age of 37.

item.title: Scott thanks inspirational Norman
item.description: Adam Scott dedicates his Masters victory to Greg Norman, saying his fellow Australian had "inspired a nation".

item.title: Garth Crooks's Team of the Week
item.description: With two FA Cup semi-finals and seven Premier League games to choose from, who has made the team of the week?

item.title: Aguero should accept blame - Luiz
item.description: Chelsea's David Luiz says Sergio Aguero should apologise for the challenge on him during Sunday's FA Cup tie.

item.title: Red Bull deny Webber 'conspiracy'
item.description: Red Bull's team principal Christian Horner says reports of a conspiracy against driver Mark Webber are "complete rubbish".

item.title: Petrol prices down at supermarkets
item.description: Supermarkets announce petrol price cuts following a fall in the wholesale cost and a more favourable exchange rate.

item.title: Gold price falls to two-year low
item.description: Gold falls to its lowest level since March 2011 after a 8.5% drop on Monday as fears of high inflation recede.

item.title: UK-EU relationship 'must change'
item.description: Business lobby group British Chambers of Commerce says most UK businesses want to stay in Europe, with some powers brought back home.

item.title: Labour 'must offer voters solutions'
item.description: Labour must offer "solutions" to voters' problems if it is to be seen as an "effective party of government", ex-Home Secretary Lord Reid says.

item.title: Scientists make 'lab-grown' kidney
item.description: A kidney "grown" in the laboratory has been transplanted into animals where it started to produce urine, US scientists say.

item.title: Parkinson's discrimination revealed
item.description: Nearly half of the people with Parkinson's disease face regular discrimination, such as having their symptoms mistaken for drunkenness, research shows.

item.title: Children 'pressed to cheat at sport'
item.description: Two-thirds of children feel under pressure to cheat at sports because of a "win-at-all-costs" culture, a survey suggests.

item.title: Science plan 'weakens sex education'
item.description: Sex education in schools is at risk of being "watered down" if proposed changes to England's science curriculum go ahead, experts have warned.

item.title: Google chief wary of mini-drones
item.description: The influential head of Google, Eric Schmidt, calls for civilian drone technology to be regulated, warning about privacy and security concerns.

item.title: Twitter move hints at music service
item.description: Micro-blogging site Twitter is rumoured to be launching a new music service after buying the music discovery site We Are Hunted.

item.title: New eyes to spy highest-energy skies
item.description: Researchers unveil the first image from a new observatory in Mexico that can catch the highest-energy light ever seen on Earth.

item.title: Biofuels are 'irrational strategy'
item.description: A new report says the UK's use of biofuels is "irrational" and will cost motorists around £460 million over the next 12 months.

item.title: Conductor Sir Colin Davis dies
item.description: The London Symphony Orchestra has announced the death of its longest-serving principal conductor, Sir Colin Davis, at the age of 85.

item.title: Avengers wins three MTV movie awards
item.description: Box office hit The Avengers beats the competition at this year's MTV movie awards, winning three of the four prizes it was nominated for.

item.title: Online bingo: A very full house
item.description: Switch on the television or flick through a newspaper and you'll see an advert for online bingo. But who is logging on to play - and why?

item.title: How US beer inspired British brewers
item.description: Once widely mocked, US beer is now popular globally with hipsters and connoisseurs alike. Why?

item.title: Fifth family crash victim named
item.description: A woman who was killed along with four family members when their car was in a collision with a lorry on the A18 near Grimsby is named by police.

item.title: Attacked police horse not hurt
item.description: A police horse which was apparently punched when trouble flared after Sunderland beat Newcastle United was not hurt, officers say.

item.title: Scottish economic recovery 'slows'
item.description: Growth in Scotland's private sector slowed at the end of the first quarter, a monthly survey of executives has found.

item.title: Road closed after section collapses
item.description: The A708 Moffat to Selkirk road in Dumfries and Galloway is closed after a large section collapsed into a stream.

item.title: Alleyway murder victim name released
item.description: Police released the name of the man who died after being assaulted in an alleyway in east Belfast in the early hours of Sunday.

item.title: Police to meet groups over UVF flags
item.description: The police will meet community and political representatives to address concerns about the erection of UVF flags in east Belfast.

item.title: Failing back-to-work scheme closed
item.description: A £36m back-to-work scheme is being wound up early because it has missed its targets, the Welsh government confirms.

item.title: Ambulance waiting exceeds six years
item.description: Ambulances spent almost 55,000 hours - equivalent to more than six years - waiting outside hospitals in six months, according to figures obtained by BBC Wales.

item.title: Chad troops start Mali pullout
item.description: Chad, one of the largest supplier of troops battling Islamists in Mali, starts to pull them out, President Idriss Deby says.

item.title: Clashes in Bangui leave '17 dead'
item.description: At least 17 people were killed in weekend clashes between residents and ex-rebels in the Central African Republic's capital, Bangui, the local Red Cross says.

item.title: Man guilty of India bakery blast
item.description: A court in India finds a man guilty for his involvement in a bomb blast that left 17 dead at a bakery in the western city of Pune in 2010.

item.title: Scott wins Masters in play-off
item.description: Adam Scott collects the first major of his career after beating Angel Cabrera at the second play-off hole at the Masters.

item.title: Cyprus to ease citizenship rules
item.description: Cyprus is to relax its citizenship rules for foreign investors who lost at least 3m euros (£2.5m) under an EU bailout deal, the Cypriot president says.

item.title: French ministers to reveal wealth
item.description: French government ministers are due to reveal details of their personal wealth as part of efforts by President Hollande to regain public trust.

item.title: Pope sets up Vatican reform body
item.description: The new Pope Francis appoints a group of top churchmen to advise him on how to reform the Vatican's often arcane bureaucracy, or curia.

item.title: Farc rebels 'could escape jail'
item.description: Colombia's attorney-general, Eduardo Montealegre, says Farc members could escape jail terms should a peace deal be struck.

item.title: Kuwait ex-MP jailed for emir insult
item.description: Prominent Kuwaiti opposition leader, Mussallam al-Barrak, is jailed for five years for insulting Emir Sheikh Sabah al-Sabah.

item.title: Blast in Bahrain raises fears for F1
item.description: A car explosion in the heart of the Bahraini capital Manama heightens security concerns ahead of Sunday's Formula 1 Grand Prix.

item.title: Hunger strike clashes at Guantanamo
item.description: Prisoners and guards clash at Guantanamo Bay as authorities move prisoners, many of whom are on hunger strike, out of communal cellblocks.

item.title: Sandy Hook mother in Obama address
item.description: The mother of a victim of last year's Sandy Hook shootings replaces Barack Obama to deliver the weekly US presidential radio address.

item.title: Day in pictures: 15 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 15 April

item.title: In pictures: Mogadishu court attack
item.description: Attack on the main court buildings in Mogadishu

item.title: In pictures: Venezuelans vote
item.description: Electing a successor to Hugo Chavez

item.title: The Stone Roses' first photographer
item.description: Ian Tilton's "ideas" and "experiments"

item.title: Week in pictures: 6-12 April 2013
item.description: A selection of photos from the news this week

item.title: Day in pictures: 12 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 12 April

item.title: In pictures: Goa's 'nomads'
item.description: Images of Goa's tribe of Western 'nomads'

item.title: In pictures: Sculptures on show
item.description: Exhibition at Salisbury Cathedral in Wiltshire

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The prime minister leads tributes to Baroness Thatcher.

item.title: VIDEO: Arrested for not smiling?
item.description: Parkinson's sufferer Mark Worsfold talks about the misunderstandings he faces as a result of his illness.

item.title: VIDEO: Airbus to trim plane window seat size
item.description: Airbus plans to reduce the size of its window seats to make room for wider ones in the aisles.

item.title: VIDEO: Marr: I'm frankly lucky to be alive
item.description: BBC presenter Andrew Marr said he was lucky to be alive as he appeared on his show for the first time since suffering a major stroke.

item.title: VIDEO: Syrian boys who sparked a revolution
item.description: In an exclusive report, the BBC's Fergal Keane speaks to some of the children whose punishment for spraying anti-regime graffiti helped sparked the country's uprising.

item.title: AUDIO: Apocalypse Now's 'surfing legacy'
item.description: The BBC's Kate McGeown explains how surfing has transformed the culture and industry in the Philippines

item.title: VIDEO: German metal band made of metal
item.description: A rock band consisting of four robots, including a four-armed drummer and a guitarist with 78 "fingers", have played their first public gigs.

item.title: VIDEO: Deadly attack on Somalia courthouse
item.description: At least 19 people have been killed in a series of bomb and gun attacks in the Somalian capital, Mogadishu.

item.title: VIDEO: Racing a marathon waist-deep in snow
item.description: The North Pole Marathon is one of the most challenging races, where participants run in punishing conditions of snow and ice while coping with temperatures of minus 30 degrees.

item.title: Exercise and strokes: What is safe?
item.description: Can short bursts of intensive exercise trigger stroke?

item.title: Why spend $250,000 on a gold shirt?
item.description: Why would you spend $250,000 on a gold shirt?

item.title: Blind drivers at the steering wheel
item.description: Will cars soon be driven by people who can't see?

item.title: Afghan farmers increase opium growth
item.description: Afghan farmers in Helmand find no market for alternative crops

item.title: How prime ministers were laid to rest
item.description: Prime ministers' funerals across the centuries

item.title: VIDEO: US teen sends bikes to India's poorest kids
item.description: The American schoolboy bringing bikes to India's poorest children

item.title: Was George III a manic depressive?
item.description: Was George III really suffering manic depression?

item.title: Welfare reform and the prosperity gap
item.description: Will benefit cuts widen 'prosperity gap'? asks Mark Easton

item.title: The Bitcoin bubble
item.description: The currency of the future, or a hobby for geeks?
